items.title: Transit employee stabbed customer first at Dundas Station last week: Toronto police
items.summary_auto: A man and a woman have been charged following a stabbing at Dundas Station last week, Toronto police say.

items.title: Belgium, Germany and Croatia to play group matches in Canada at 2026 World Cup
items.summary_auto: Germany, Belgium and Croatia are among the teams that will play games in Canada in group play at next summer's FIFA World Cup. The full schedule of the expanded 48-team, 104-game tournament was announced Saturday in Washington D.C.

items.title: Inter Miami defeats Vancouver Whitecaps 3-1 to win its first MLS Cup
Canada has legal duty to provide safe water, housing to remote First Nations, federal judge rules
items.summary_auto: A federal judge has sided with two First Nations in Manitoba and one in Ontario that sued the Canadian government over its duty to provide them with safe housing and clean drinking water, in separate rulings delivered Friday.

items.title: Indigenous cultural belongings return to Canada from Vatican after long journey
Russia unleashes massive drone and missile attack on Ukraine amid diplomatic talks
items.summary_auto: Russia unleashed a major missile and drone barrage on Ukraine overnight into Saturday, after U.S. and Ukrainian officials said theyâ€™ll meet on Saturday for a third day of talks aimed at ending the nearly four-year-old war.

items.title: Lost for 5 months in the Northern Rockies, this cat is heading home to Oklahoma for Christmas
items.summary_auto: After five months lost in northeastern B.C, a beloved family cat is heading home for the holidays. Since July, Shadow the cat has been surviving in the wilderness of the Northern Rockies.

items.title: Mortal Kombat star Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa dead at 75
items.summary_auto: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, a Tokyo-born actor known for his roles in the film Mortal Kombat and TV series The Man in the High Castle, has died. He was 75.

items.title: New restrictions placed on hunting, farming 'incredibly destructive' wild boars in Alberta
items.summary_auto: Wild boars have been declared "a pest in all circumstances" by the Alberta government effective Dec. 1, meaning new restrictions have been placed on keeping them in captivity and hunting them in the wild.

items.title: Why Danielle Smith's government is not withstanding many court challenges
items.summary_auto: From transgender policies to referendums to "conservative" party names, the Alberta UCP has stepped in where others have feared to tread.

items.title: Family, friends remember para athlete, reality TV star and 'fierce' disability advocate
items.summary_auto: Brian McPherson, an Edmonton-based pioneer in adaptive bobsled and star of the CBC TV show, Push, died on Nov. 12. He was 47.

items.title: Some Halifax Explosion artifacts pulled from the harbour will have a new home
items.summary_auto: Almost a year and a half after pieces of the Mont-Blanc were discovered during dredging in Halifax harbour, plans are starting to take shape for what to do with some of the wreckage from the famed ship involved in the Halifax Explosion.

items.title: But you don't have Canadian experience: That phrase tore me down as an immigrant but also made me resilient
items.summary_auto: Hari KC's qualifications were good enough for him to qualify to immigrate to Canada but not to work here. Becoming a security guard and then going back to school taught him how to rebuild his life one step at a time and shaped his understanding of what diversity in Canada means.

items.title: Montreal honours 14 victims of Polytechnique massacre at ceremony
items.summary_auto: A total of 14 women were murdered in the mass shooting on Dec. 6, 1989. Thirteen others were injured in the attack.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | This week's most compelling images
items.summary_auto: Photographers from CBC News, The Canadian Press, Reuters and others document our changing world every day. Here's a selection of the week's top images.

items.title: Accused woman blames Children's Aid Society and eating disorder for child's death, court hears
items.summary_auto: In a note written six months after a child died in her care, Becky Hamber said she was not to blame for his death, a Milton, Ont., court heard Friday.
